metadata.titel_preek: Night of Shame, Night of Glory

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The Son of God enters the agony of Gethsemane and the shame of the Cross to take upon himself the divine judgment against sin, thereby ransoming and liberating humanity.

tekstueel_bewijs: the Son of God declares himself ready to lay down his life
he is preparing... to give us all the vitamins tomorrow
Jesus... was preparing to be separated from the Father
he takes that condemnation away from us
to give his life as a ransom for many
there is therefore now no condemnation

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Holiness of God
tekstueel_bewijs: in the mystery of his will and purpose he has chosen you
God, sending his own Son... condemned sin in the flesh
he has chosen you to be here
those saved by his blood will be many... we ourselves
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer identifies strictly as the Receiver of a finished work.

helper.identificatie: The Angel / The Holy Spirit (implied in 'state of grace')
tekstueel_bewijs: there appeared to him an angel from heaven, strengthening him
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject (Son) and the Sender (Father); the Helper is a subordinate celestial agent.
helper.rol_van_geest: The Spirit is the medium of the 'state of grace' that allows the hearer to recognize sin.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Death, and the 'Ugliness' of Human Cruelty
tekstueel_bewijs: preparing to meet Sin and Death disarmed
the ultimate cruelty that lurks in the human heart
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not a bad habit but an ontological power requiring the 'total obliteration' and 'separation' of the Son from the Father.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The response of the redeemed community: loving one another and giving oneself back to Christ in gratitude.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer / The Church
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ethical response (Program 2) is explicitly fueled by the 'motive power' of the soteriological work (Program 1).

voorbeelden_god_subject: Jesus draws us very close to himself.
God has condemned sin in the flesh of Jesus.
He takes that condemnation away from us.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We love, because he first loved us.
We cannot achieve freedom... through our own spiritual striving.

voorbeelden: We are not commanded to love one another in order to win our way.
To know sin is to be already in a state of grace.
We cannot achieve freedom... through our own spiritual striving.
The victory is given to us as a present.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes the human 'non-pouvoir' (inability) which is met by the divine 'pouvoir' (victory as a gift).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from the 'Night of Shame' (niet-S1) to the 'Agony' (S2) where Christ absorbs S2 to move the hearer to 'Glory' (niet-S2/S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Substitutionary: Christ occupies S2 so the Receiver can occupy S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; S2 is described as 'horror-stricken,' 'excrement,' and 'separation from the Father.'

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is rigorously theocentric. God/Christ is the primary actor of all salvific verbs, while the human role is defined by reception and subsequent gratitude.

indicatoren_moralisme.indicator: Potential for Exemplarism in the mother's vitamin story
indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: The mother doled out the pills... how much more does our Father

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: We are not commanded to love one another in order to win our way into God's favor; we are already in his favor.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: Subject-Switch (Christ as the one who does what we cannot)
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: We cannot achieve freedom... the victory is given to us as a present.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures (David, the Disciples) are used as examples of people who *receive* or *confess*, not as heroes to emulate in power.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading of David.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and gratitude; removal of the burden of self-salvation.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic sanctification (gratitude as the only engine for ethics).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'Fundamental Program' (Salvation) to the 'Secondary Program' (Ethics) is perfectly handled via the bridge of gratitude.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: He takes that condemnation away from us... in so doing, he takes that condemnation away from us.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon focuses on the work of the Son, with the Spirit's role being implicit in the 'state of grace' and 'new community'.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is defined as something so ugly it requires the 'blood and excrement' of the cross to solve.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is powered by Christ's agency. The hearer is positioned as a beneficiary of a cosmic transaction.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain current balance for a Maundy Thursday context.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The sermon successfully avoids the 'Devoir' trap.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a masterclass in grace-oriented homiletics. It uses high-stakes narrative tension to highlight human inability and divine sufficiency.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'family' metaphor, Greimasian analysis reveals that the 'family' is a result of a specific actantial shift (Christ as Subject).
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Greek for 'agony'; semiotics explains *why* that agony is the necessary 'performance' phase for the Subject to achieve the Object.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the sermon's power comes from the 'Subject-Switch'—the hearer is explicitly told they *cannot* be the Subject of their own freedom.

appendices.notities: The sermon by Fleming Rutledge perfectly exemplifies her own 'Grammar of Grace' rules.
